job_title: Graduate Assistantship in Kansas City, MO
pros: Full tuition is covered Flexible working hours

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Parkville, MO
pros: You get every federal holiday off.
cons: Literally everything about Park is a con.

pros: Flexibility but that has started to become less than. Nice people to work with.
cons: The politics are daunting. There are no pay increases. Removed bonuses 1 year before COVID without any communication. Communication from higher ups are strange and not informative. Feels like the lower staff are not valued but the executives get all of the benefits and pay.

pros: Nice small and friendly campus. Employees' children can complete their education for free. University onboarding process is reasonable. The faculty has a union.
cons: The salary is not good. Depending on your department, some are not organized. They have a diversity issue. They have high turnover with staff and faculty, especially with people of color. They may change your contract.

pros: The campus is a nice location and easy to drive to. I liked the location and some of the people who I worked with. It is a great starting point for many people to get experience.
cons:
Low salary. Look up the industry standard and cut it in half. Ask for salary information if you move on to an on campus visit. Ask for the highest salary range. 
There is not a lot of diversity. It is very very traditional and not in a good way. You will not see a lot of women in the high leadership positions or people of color.

review_title: Low pay, not interested in change, and good luck if you're staff
pros: The people you work with on the ground level (i.e. "the grunts") are there for the students and are always trying to work to get things done, despite what the C-Suite are doing. Benefits are normal of higher ed and so are more competitive against corporate setting (but not by much).
cons: Extremely low pay compared to competitors, no real opportunities for advancement or pay raise, not a diverse workplace, C-Suite and other higher-ups are constantly getting in the way of real progress. C-Suite are always coming up with ridiculous ideas that don't work (but cost tons of money) and impede the jobs of those of us who are student-facing/getting real work done. I once had a complaint against a faculty member and was told by a higher-up not to bother going to HR about it because "They'll just laugh in your face and no one will believe you." They will do everything to protect their faculty but don't care about the staff. Staff have enormous turnover and they just shrug and do nothing about it--even though everyone knows what the issues are, none of it gets fixed. They also talk a lot about work/life balance but don't actually execute on any of it: if you're not getting it done after hours, you will hear about it and be made to feel guilty for not putting in more time (even though they certainly aren't going to compensate you for it either).

job_title: Campus Center Director in Havelock, NC
pros: Flexibility, location, diverse student population
cons: Compensation, limited mobility, job security

job_title: Campus Center Director in Havelock, NC
pros: Military friendly aboard MCAS Cherry Point.

job_title: Testing Coordinator in Hill AFB, UT
pros: The staff at Park was extremely friendly and easy to work with. I was a part time employee, so my schedule was a little bit flexible. It was easy to feel like you were making a difference in the lives of students as you helped them schedule and take their proctored exams.
cons: The location at Hill Air Force Base was sometimes cold because the base heating system didn't always work.

pros: Time off, students, people that work there.
cons: No real incentive to overachieve.

job_title: Associate Professor in Kansas City, MO
pros:
The staff, faculty and  students have long been the primary reason people come to Park University to work and learn. The  new administration, under the leadership of Dr. Greg Gunderson, have made significant strides in increased enrollment, student, staff, and faculty satisfaction and enhanced use of technology and other cutting edge innovations across the institution. 

The location is fantastic as it offers a short walk into the quaint and inviting downtown Parkville with dozens of local businesses and restaurants, while downtown Kansas City is a quick 15 minute drive. 

North Kansas City offers dozens of well known businesses, popular restaurants and family friendly entertainment, including The Main Event, Power Play, and more! The choices for schools and places to worship are extensive, and my family and I never lack for something interesting todo on the weekends!
cons: The university is transitioning to more innovation and expansion of programs, which is revealing shortages in staff and faculty support. Between the now 42 Camus centers and ever increasing online student growth, the need for high quality and qualified professionals is well known; however, Park University is situated within driving distance of several other significantly larger For Profit institutions who offer competitive compensation opportunities for the same hiring pool of professionals. Competition is good and in this area it is high!

pros: Flexibility in scheduling, Great part time job.
cons: None I can think of!

pros: Good for entry level jobs
cons: Bad bad bad bad bad

pros:
Beautiful Campus!
I love all of the full-time staff members I work with and we really all try to work together as a team 
Learn how to multitask and handle student concerns
Get off on almost all national holidays
cons:
An ABUNDANCE of miscommunication between departments (If you ask one person, you won't get the same answer from another on who to report to)
Stressful and tiring at times trying to get answers that match up between departments
Parking is terrible
Only Paid Monthly (budgeting is key)
Although there have been some advances in technology and equipment, there are still several systems that need improvement.

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Parkville, MO
pros: My team/coworkers are great.  Direct supervisor is supportive and kind and willing to listen.  The dept itself is good and communication within the division is pretty good and transparent.  The senior administration is visible on-campus and holds annual forums for direct communication/feedback from staff/faculty. There are opportunities for advancement here as HR posts jobs internally before they post them externally.
cons: outdated software, lack in transparency regarding budgets/finances within dept., lack of team-building and motivational experiences (retreats, etc.), lack of professional development for hourly or non-exempt staff. The PAY is well below the national average for the position and benefits are fairly expensive (although they are working on a new salary structure to better align the pay).

review_title: THIS IS A GREAT PLACE TO WORK!!!
pros: All of the staff really care about one another.  It is a very "family friendly" place to work!  By and large, the management of the university hires competent people and then stays out of their way and lets them do their job.  The hands off approach to management is appreciated by many.
cons: The same hands off approach described above, comes with a downside.  There is little acknowledgement of a job well done.  If you need recognition and kudos from others to be happy in your work life,  this is NOT the environment for you.  Compensation is at the low end for comparable highter education positions in this area.

pros: Very friendly, supportive faculty and staff members. The students are great, fun to work with, very motivated in general.
cons:
Please, as you read these reviews about Park University, note that a lot of the good ones are from adjunct faculty members, student workers and employees from the campus centers. Their opinions are relevant for people looking for jobs in those respective roles. However, if you are applying for a full-time faculty or staff position in Parkville, please focus on the other reviews, which are almost unanimously awful. Please ignore the December 5, 2017 review, which is (comically) obviously written by administration. 

Park is not a good place to work. Staff are treated poorly, while HR smiles in your face and tells you how wonderful it is. The salaries are very low. Disturbing biases in hiring and promotion that are only getting lip service from the administration. Please, seriously consider any offer before accepting. Very divisive, exclusionary environment that is not conducive to teamwork. I can't wait to get out.

review_title: Think twice about accepting a position here right now.
pros: Excellent departmental management, great tuition remission program.
cons: School is currently having some financial issues, interdepartmental conflict is rarely-if ever-addressed, little to no chance of moving up unless someone dies or retires.  The pay is a little low for the amount of work that most employees are expected to do.  With layoffs and shake-ups, you're picking up a LOT of slack from other departments.

pros: Great school, great people, and I can't remember a bad experience their.  I wouldn't change anything except perhaps some of the fundamental operating philosophies at the top-level, other than that most Professors are excellent and a few are hit or miss.
cons: No Greek life.  Some of the greatest friendships in one's life can blossom from fraternal groups, I don't know what the big deal is, besides alcohol of course.  The campus is beautiful but not a lot of gathering, grassy areas (courtyards, etc.)  Otherwise, what a great experience, everyone was friendly.

pros: Old run down but still attractive campus.
cons: Third Director of Campus Safety in 8 months. No support for the position due to some hidden baggage in the department and in the administration. I've been at Park for 7 years and the last Director of Campus Safety was excellent but he quietly went away like all of the others. This is a university that is a cancer to itself. The new president is not being told what is really going on. There is no priority for safety here. Great example is that the Director of Safety reports to the head of maintenance. There are people concerned about their safety here but Campus Safety is not allowed to talk about issues. I don't recommend this position or any other. There is no job security here. People disappear on a regular basis.

job_title: Administrative/Program Specialist in Camp Pendleton, CA
pros: The employees who work for the company are able to take classes free or at a discounted rate. I think it's great to know that you are assisting adults and military member further their education. It's never too late to learn something new, and learning should be a lifetime goal for everyone. There is always new information out there, and it opens yourself up for other opportunities.
cons: I do not believe management is aware that there is more training needed in order to help adult learners and military members. Some of the staff members lack compassion, understanding, and patience when it comes to giving the students the customer service they deserve. This training can be gathered through seminars that are offered on a regular basis. I feel the company needs to invest more in their employees and give them regular feedback. More than anything, give the campus centers goals that are attainable for the long-term, and understand that it does not run like a traditional campus unless more manpower is allowed at the campus center level.

review_title: Part-time Adjunct Professor at Park University
pros: Small feel to this university.  Friendly staff.  Loyal to employees.  Supportive of student needs as well.
cons: Part-time adjuncts are NOT paid on a monthly basis.  Rather, they are paid once during the middle of semester, and once on completion of the semester, which translates to a bit less than every two months. For Greater Kansas City area this rate is a little below the norm.

job_title: Adjunct Criminal Justice Instructor in Jacksonville, AR
pros: Great support from staff and coworkers, great pay, great students. The only reason I left my position was I relocated.
cons: I do not have any Cons for this job.  I enjoyed every aspect of my job at Park University.

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Kansas City, MO
pros: People who work here are very nice. It has a small community feel and a very friendly environment. I feel valued and appreciated for the work i put into the organization.
cons: The financial aid department is very understaffed and at times unorganized. The computer system that is used in the process is outdated. 25% of the time is spent talking to angry students or parents of the students about the financial aid process.

job_title: Campus Center Director in Great Falls, MT
pros: Great benefits. Good hours. Higher level administration is really trying to make Park U a great place to work. Amazing vacation/holidays/sick time. Loved my immediate staff and direct supervisor was fair and very good to work with.
cons: Micro-management, high pressure to increase enrollments with small marketing budget. Salaries are lower than average. Not a lot of room to move up within the university. As staff left, positions were not filled, still expected to increase enrollments with less staff.

review_title: The position I accepted was not the same as stated in the interview and job description.
job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Parkville, MO
pros: I loved working with the students. Tuition is free for employees and I think it's also free for family members.
cons: Low pay, salary employees are paid monthly, lack of communication through management, high turnover..FA dept is clueless, no room for growth

pros:

pros: Campus is beautiful and staff/faculty are nice.  Free education for self, spouse and children.
cons: Leadership is a mess.  Promotions are given under the table to select “good ole boys” group.  No promoting from within.   They like to keep staff in current positions and hire “smarter” outside people for more interesting and challenging jobs.  Very discouraged and frustrated staff.

pros: Great opportunity to connect students to great education. Great adjunct faculty. Great for developing communication skills, event planning skills, and marketing skills.
cons: Salary not commiserate to position tasks or requirements. Micromanagement. Too laden with administrative folks. Salary is the same nationwide...no adjustment for locale, but requires same education and experience.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: Nice environment.  Great students.  Good quality Canvas courses are easy to deliver.  Administrative stuff is very helpful.   You need to follow the teaching standard to keep us with the requirements.
cons: Some students are challenging, which is pretty normal.   Some courses need some work/input from the instructor, which I found interesting.

pros: Great students, beautiful (if decrepit) campus, nice colleagues
cons: This place is a mess.  Salaries are lower than national averages, lower than regional averages. Little to no salary increases every single year, while benefits get more expensive. Promotions seem to be reserved for certain races and genders. Everything is a secret. Everything is political. No shared governance. Stay away.

pros: Some very nice faculty and staff... Good to work with...
cons: 2015 University did a Retrenchment 1/3 of faculty and RIF of staff.  A Big cave in in the underground.  Top management us gone as well. Not a good place to work for.

review_title: My 5-year experience has been mixed: good co-workers, troubled administration and financial picture.
